vectorData.altText:
19. Identify the structure of the lymph node paracortex outlined in the image. 
Hint: T cells migrate through these structures into the lymph node.
That’s right!  T cells migrate into LN paracortex through the high endothelial venules (HEVs).
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

In the cortex, B cells form lymphoid nodules. With the arrival of antigen in afferent lymph, nodules develop germinal centres due to the proliferation and differentiation of stimulated B cells. The resultant plasma cells migrate to the medulla. The antibodies they produce leave via efferent lymph.
In the paracortex, T cells dominate and lymph nodules are absent. Here, resident APCs process soluble antigen arriving in afferent lymph and present it to T cells for recognition. High endothelial venules, HEVs, in the paracortex are the point of entry of lymphocytes arriving at the lymph node from the blood circulation. Activated T cells leave via efferent lymph for distribution.
In the medulla, medullary cords are separated by medullary sinuses. The medullary cords contain B cells, plasma cells, and macrophages. Antibodies produced by plasma cells of the medulla, leave via efferent lymph for systemic distribution.
Soluble antigen, micro-organisms, APCs bearing antigenic epitopes and lymphocytes arrive at the lymph node from peripheral tissues via afferent lymph.

T cells dominate in the paracortex, having entered the node via the high endothelial venules, HEVs. 
Activated T cells enlarge and proliferate to form expanded clones that are distributed via efferent lymph to peripheral tissues.
